p.s: William Shakespeare'sSonnet 60 was written between the end of the 16th and the beginning of the 17th century.
It is mainly about how life, despite its beauty, focesforces a cruel and inevitable end.
The sonnet has the tpyical structure of a sonnet, containing 14 verses with ten to eleven syllables each, three quatrains with a crossing rhyme and a rhyming couplet at the end.
It is also written in an iambic pentameter, meaning that in each verse one syllable is accented and the next one is not.
This gives the sonnet the effect of a heartbeat so the readers know that the writer of the sonnet really relates or feels what he writes.
The first two quatrains, as usual, introduce or develop the idea of the sonnet:
The first quatrain is about how life slowly comes to an end and there is nothing anyone can do about it.
The second quatrain illustrates the process of life, from being born to growing up.
Then there is a turn between the second and the third quatrain, a so called volta.

While the first two quatrains talk about a human's life from birth to death, the third quatrain focuses on what happends to a human and what time does to hum after growing up, his excitement for life fading away, him being unaware of life's beauty anymore etc.
In the third quatrain the reader can precisely understand what happens with one's psyche on the way to death which is completely different from the first two quatrains.
The couplet then summarizes the idea of the sonnet.

The writer reaches this by saying that despite the cruelness of life he wants to show his love and in a way he tries to say that his lover made life and the thought of dealing with death a bit easier for him.
In order for his idea to be more understandable, Shakespeare uses a few lyrical devices.
At the beginning of the sonnet there is a comparison: Like as the waves make towards the pebbled shore, So do our minutes hasten to their end (ll. 1-2).
He compares life with waves, like the waves head towards the shore, life heads towards death.
This comparison shows not only that life will come to an end no matter what, but also that it is beautiful while it lasts.
Because as we know waves are beautiful to watch and people enjoy them, just like they should enjoy life while they are able to.
Also in line two he uses the word our when he talks about death.
In that way he stresses that he is describing a process which concerns everyone.
Another lyrical device Shakespeare uses is a metaphor in the second quatrain.
He portrays being an adult as a human's main goal, as he describes it as being crowned (l. 6).
Also he mentions the word glory (l. 7), which illustrates the same idea.
Another metaphor is the word gift (l. 6).
While talking about what happens to humans when time goes by he uses the word gift which shows the worth of a human.
For Shakespeare, a human is a gift which unfortunately gets taken away.
The writer then uses an alliteration ('gainst, glory, gave, gift (ll. 7-8)), intending to stress the importance of the process of growing up.
Because in the first 16 years of a person's life he focuses on growing: physically, mentally and emotionally.
In the third quatrain there is a personification of time Time doth transfix the fourish set on youth(l. 9).
By personifying time in that way the writer stressing what time is able to bring about.
Of course, time itself cannot do anything as it is no person, but Shakespeare wants the reader to understand what can happen with time, which is quite a lot.
Another personification can be found in the third quatrain as well.
This time the scythe is personified [...] for his scythe to mow(l. 12).
This personification is just a different expression for dying.
A scythe is typical for death.
People mostly associate death with a black-hooded man with a scull for a head and a scythe.
So instead of directly mentioning death Shakespeare describes it as a scythe mowing.
Finally, in the couplet, the speaker addresses the addressee directly for the first time in the sonnet.
He does that by firstly talking about his own verse and then addressing his lover's worth Praising thy worth, [...], (l. 14).
To sum up one can say that Shakespeare's Sonnet 60 is a very meaningful poem which deals with the problems, as well as the reasons to enjoy life.
It is also a sonnet filled with lyrical devices which bring the reader as close as possible to the writers mind and thoughts.
